repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Food Crisis
            Response Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Central African Republic Food Crisis
            Response Project had an overall moderately satisfactory
            outcome with a high risk to development outcome and
            moderately satisfactory performances by both the Bank and
            borrower. Some of the lessons learned include: (1) intense
            implementation support for emergency operations prepared
            under OP 8.0 will often be needed immediately following
            effectiveness to rapidly close any readiness gaps and ensure
            successful outcomes; (2) while OP 8.0 does provide increased
            flexibility in preparing emergency operations, for small
            operations of this nature, Bank procedures may still be too
            onerous; (3) outsourcing implementation to non-governmental
            partners can be an effective strategy in fragile states; (4)
            weak institutional capacity within key ministries hinders
            development impact from Bank investments, but cannot be
            adequately addressed through emergency operations; (5) The
            GFRP Trust Fund facilitated the Banks reengagement in
            agriculture in CAR; (6) non-traditional partners can
            introduce new and innovative ways of doing things.

repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Food Response
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Food Response
            Project for the Central African Republic is to: i) provide
            increased food access to primary and pre-school students in
            targeted areas; and ii) support rural producer's
            capacity to ensure adequate supply response for medium-term
            improvement in food security. The requested extension will
            provide sufficient time for the completion of the 22-month
            subsidiary agreements. The client and the World Bank have
            agreed on a time-bound action plan for accelerating project
            implementation and achieving project goals. The action plan
            provides a government commitment to prepare annual reviews
            of compliance with action plan and performance indicators.
            At the core of the action plan is a list of time-bound
            actions that the Permanent Technical Committee of Structural
            Adjustment Programs (CTP/PAS) and other government entities
            have committed to undertaking in order to meet the revised
            closing date and avoid further delays in the implementation
            of components two and three.

repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Emergency Food
            Response Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The projects overall development
            objectives are to: (i) provide increased food access to
            primary and pre-school students in targeted areas; and (ii)
            support farmers capacity to ensure adequate supply response
            for medium-term improvement in food security. The negative
            effects on the human environment are: risks associated with
            the use of pesticides by farmers themselves; conflicts
            relating to law and land use (cohabitation between various
            rights, claims in each village); potential conflicts between
            agriculture and livestock and the development of waterborne
            disease (an increased prevalence of malaria, increased cases
            of dysentery, an increase of schistosomiasis, ...), the risk
            of diversion objectives of the project (changes to other
            beneficiaries than originally envisaged because of
            difficulties in development); risks to health and safety in
            pesticide management (contamination by livestock watering;
            poisoning in cases of misuse; residues on products, poor
            management of packaging, etc..), the depletion and
            degradation of water sources; the conflicts over land use or
            water and possible cumulative effects of a breakdown, the
            inequitable access rights to land or water (particularly
            women), difficulties regarding the integration of women in
            agricultural activities. On the biophysical environment, the
            major potential negative impacts include: loss of vegetation
            and reduction of biodiversity in deforestation and clearing
            of plots; degradation due to soil salinization, soil
            acidification, the drop in fertility due to cultivation
            practices, soil erosion, loss or reduction of land for
            pasture degradation of water quality (pollution of streams
            and lakes).
